claim: Use the Sean Ellis test: if 40%+ users say they'd be 'very disappointed' without your product, you likely have PMF. Below 40% indicates continued iteration needed.
rationale: The 40% threshold indicates a critical mass of users view the product as indispensable. This quantitative benchmark cuts through vanity metrics to measure genuine product necessity.

claim: Validate Problem-Solution Fit through customer interviews before building product. Talk to 50-100 potential customers to confirm the problem is real and significant.
rationale: Building without validating leads to products nobody wants. Extensive customer discovery reduces risk by ensuring you're solving a genuine, widespread problem before committing resources.

claim: Achieve deep PMF in a narrow niche before expanding to broader markets. Become indispensable to a specific group, then leverage success to grow.
rationale: Targeting too many segments dilutes the value proposition. Focused efforts on a well-defined early adopter group create traction, advocacy, and learnings to fuel expansion.

claim: High organic growth and word-of-mouth indicate strong PMF. When customers market your product for you, acquisition costs drop and growth becomes sustainable.
rationale: Products with true PMF pull customers in organically. Heavy marketing spend to acquire customers who quickly churn signals the product doesn't genuinely solve their problem.

claim: Track retention and churn rates as primary PMF indicators. Low churn signals users find ongoing value; high churn reveals the product fails to deliver sustained worth.
rationale: Acquisition without retention is unsustainable. Customers staying and deriving continued value proves the product has integrated into their lives, the hallmark of genuine PMF.

claim: Building based on assumptions rather than validated customer needs leads to products nobody wants. Without customer discovery, products solve imaginary problems.
rationale: Founders often fall in love with their idea without testing it. The result is technically impressive products that fail because they don't address real market pain points.

claim: Scaling before achieving PMF accelerates resource consumption on a product that doesn't resonate. Premature scaling leads to unsustainable burn and eventual failure.
rationale: Without PMF, scaling amplifies inefficiency. Expensive customer acquisition yields high churn, negative unit economics, and capital exhaustion before the product proves market value.

claim: Chasing too many customer segments simultaneously dilutes value propositions. Products that try to be everything to everyone end up being nothing special to anyone.
rationale: Broad targeting prevents deep understanding of any segment's needs. Resources scatter, messaging becomes generic, and the product fails to become indispensable anywhere.

claim: Constant pivoting without sufficient testing prevents any idea from gaining traction. 'Pivotitis' exhausts teams, confuses customers, and wastes the effort needed to validate concepts.
rationale: Ideas require sustained effort to test properly. Reacting to every piece of feedback or competitor move prevents systematic learning about what truly resonates.

claim: High NPS (above 50) with strong Promoter percentage indicates enthusiastic users who actively recommend the productâ€”a hallmark of strong PMF.
rationale: Promoters scoring 9-10 are not just satisfied but evangelists. High NPS combined with qualitative feedback reveals which segments experience genuine product-market resonance.

claim: Net Revenue Retention above 100% indicates existing customers are expanding their usage, signaling strong PMF and growth potential from current base.
rationale: NRR above 100% means revenue from existing customers grows despite churn. This proves the product delivers enough value that customers upgrade and expand usage.

claim: The Build-Measure-Learn loop from Lean Startup enables systematic PMF pursuit. Develop MVPs, test with users, analyze results, then iterate or pivot based on evidence.
rationale: This cycle transforms entrepreneurship from guesswork to validated learning. Rapid feedback loops minimize wasted resources by ensuring every iteration moves toward market fit.

claim: Airbnb founders personally visited early New York listings to take photos and improve descriptions, directly solving trust and quality issues that blocked conversions.
rationale: This hands-on approach addressed a critical friction point. High-quality photos and descriptions dramatically improved conversion rates by building trust between strangers.

claim: Slack pivoted from a failed game to focus on its internal communication tool when the team realized the tool was more valuable than the game itself.
rationale: Dogfooding revealed the real value. The team's own deep use of the communication tool validated it solved a genuine workplace problem worth pursuing.

claim: Netflix pivoted from DVD-by-mail to streaming to original content, repeatedly redefining its value proposition to maintain PMF as consumer entertainment needs evolved.
rationale: Netflix anticipated market shifts and strategically pivoted before being disrupted. Each transformation addressed emerging customer needs while building competitive moats.
